info.description: QuantiModo makes it easy to retrieve normalized user data from a wide array of devices and applications. [Learn about QuantiModo](https://quantimo.do), check out our [docs](https://github.com/QuantiModo/docs) or contact us at [help.quantimo.do](https://help.quantimo.do).
info.title: quantimodo

tags.name: measurements
tags.description: Measurements are any value that can be recorded like daily steps, a mood rating, or apples eaten.

tags.name: reminders
tags.description: Users can be reminded to track certain variables at a specified frequency with a default value.

tags.name: connectors
tags.description: Import data from third-party apps and devices like Fitbit and Mint.

effectVariableNameParam.name: effectVariableName
effectVariableNameParam.description: Variable name of the hypothetical effect variable.  Example: Overall Mood

causeVariableNameParam.name: causeVariableName
causeVariableNameParam.description: Variable name of the hypothetical cause variable.  Example: Sleep Duration

connectorNamePathParam.name: connectorName
connectorNamePathParam.description: Lowercase system name of the source application or device. Get a list of available connectors from the /v3/connectors/list endpoint.

variableCategoryNameParam.name: variableCategoryName
variableCategoryNameParam.description: Limit results to a specific variable category

sortParam.name: sort
sortParam.description: Sort by one of the listed field names. If the field name is prefixed with `-`, it will sort in descending order.

latestMeasurementTimeParam.name: latestMeasurementTime
latestMeasurementTimeParam.description: Excluded records with measurement times later than this value. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local.

earliestMeasurementTimeParam.name: earliestMeasurementTime
earliestMeasurementTimeParam.description: Excluded records with measurement times earlier than this value. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local.

createdAtParam.name: createdAt
createdAtParam.description: When the record was first created. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local.

updatedAtParam.name: updatedAt
updatedAtParam.description: When the record was last updated. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local.

offsetParam.name: offset
offsetParam.description: OFFSET says to skip that many rows before beginning to return rows to the client. OFFSET 0 is the same as omitting the OFFSET clause.If both OFFSET and LIMIT appear, then OFFSET rows are skipped before starting to count the LIMIT rows that are returned.

limitParam.name: limit
limitParam.description: The LIMIT is used to limit the number of results returned. So if youhave 1000 results, but only want to the first 10, you would set this to 10 and offset to 0. The maximum limit is 200 records.

get.description:
Get embeddable connect javascript. Usage:
  - Embedding in applications with popups for 3rd-party authentication
windows.
    Use `qmSetupInPopup` function after connecting `connect.js`.
  - Embedding in applications with popups for 3rd-party authentication
windows.
    Requires a selector to block. It will be embedded in this block.
    Use `qmSetupOnPage` function after connecting `connect.js`.
  - Embedding in mobile applications without popups for 3rd-party
authentication.
    Use `qmSetupOnMobile` function after connecting `connect.js`.
    If using in a Cordova application call  `qmSetupOnIonic` function after connecting `connect.js`.

parameters.name: clientId
parameters.description: Your app's client id

get.description: This page is designed to be opened in a webview.  Instead of using popup authentication boxes, it uses redirection. You can include the user's access_token as a URL parameter like https://app.quantimo.do/api/v3/connect/mobile?access_token=123

A connector pulls data from other data providers using their API or a screenscraper. Returns a list of all available connectors and information about them such as their id, name, whether the user has provided access, logo url, connection instructions, and the update history.

get.summary: Obtain a token from 3rd party data source
get.description: Attempt to obtain a token from the data provider, store it in the database. With this, the connector to continue to obtain new user data until the token is revoked.

get.description: Get correlations based on data from a single user.

parameters.name: correlationCoefficient
parameters.description: Pearson correlation coefficient between cause and effect after lagging by onset delay and grouping by duration of action

parameters.name: onsetDelay
parameters.description: The amount of time in seconds that elapses after the predictor/stimulus event before the outcome as perceived by a self-tracker is known as the “onset delay”. For example, the “onset delay” between the time a person takes an aspirin (predictor/stimulus event) and the time a person perceives a change in their headache severity (outcome) is approximately 30 minutes.

parameters.name: durationOfAction
parameters.description: The amount of time over which a predictor/stimulus event can exert an observable influence on an outcome variable’s value. For instance, aspirin (stimulus/predictor) typically decreases headache severity for approximately four hours (duration of action) following the onset delay.

parameters.name: outcomesOfInterest
parameters.description: Only include correlations for which the effect is an outcome of interest for the user

get.description: Get explanations of  correlations based on data from a single user.
Get correlations based on the anonymized aggregate data from all QuantiModo users.

parameters.name: correlationCoefficient
parameters.description: Pearson correlation coefficient between cause and effect after lagging by onset delay and grouping by duration of action

parameters.name: onsetDelay
parameters.description: The amount of time in seconds that elapses after the predictor/stimulus event before the outcome as perceived by a self-tracker is known as the “onset delay”. For example, the “onset delay” between the time a person takes an aspirin (predictor/stimulus event) and the time a person perceives a change in their headache severity (outcome) is approximately 30 minutes.

parameters.name: durationOfAction
parameters.description: The amount of time over which a predictor/stimulus event can exert an observable influence on an outcome variable’s value. For instance, aspirin (stimulus/predictor) typically decreases headache severity for approximately four hours (duration of action) following the onset delay.

parameters.name: outcomesOfInterest
parameters.description: Only include correlations for which the effect is an outcome of interest for the user

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: Provides correlation data

get.description:
Measurements are any value that can be recorded like daily steps, a mood rating, or apples eaten. Supported filter parameters:
  • value - Value of measurement
  • updatedAt - The time that this measurement was created or last updated in the UTC format "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Measurement id

parameters.name: variableName
parameters.description: Name of the variable you want measurements for

parameters.name: sourceName
parameters.description: ID of the source you want measurements for (supports exact name match only)

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: Value of measurement

parameters.name: unitAbbreviatedName
parameters.description: The unit you want the measurements returned in

parameters.name: groupingWidth
parameters.description: The time (in seconds) over which measurements are grouped together

parameters.name: groupingTimezone
parameters.description: The time (in seconds) over which measurements are grouped together

post.summary: Post a new set or update existing measurements to the database
post.description: You can submit or update multiple measurements in a "measurements" sub-array.  If the variable these measurements correspond to does not already exist in the database, it will be automatically added.  The request body should look something like [{"measurements":[{"startTime":1439389320,"value":"3"}, {"startTime":1439389319,"value":"2"}],"name":"Acne (out of 5)","source":"QuantiModo","category":"Symptoms","combinationOperation":"MEAN","unit":"/5"}]

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: An array of measurement sets containing measurement items you want to insert.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The startTime and variableId of the measurement to be deleted.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The id as well as the new startTime, note, and/or value of the measurement to be updated

post.description: Use this endpoint to schedule a CSV export containing all user measurements to be emailed to the user within 24 hours.

get.description: You can implement OAuth2 authentication to your application using our **OAuth2** endpoints.  You need to redirect users to `/api/v2/oauth/authorize` endpoint to get an authorization code and include the parameters below.   This page will ask the user if they want to allow a client's application to submit or obtain data from their QM account. It will redirect the user to the url provided by the client application with the code as a query parameter or error in case of an error. See the /api/v2/oauth/access_token endpoint for the next steps.

parameters.name: clientId
parameters.description: This is the unique ID that QuantiModo uses to identify your application. Obtain a client id by creating a free application at [https://app.quantimo.do/api/v2/apps](https://app.quantimo.do/api/v2/apps).

parameters.name: client_secret
parameters.description: This is the secret for your obtained clientId. QuantiModo uses this to validate that only your application uses the clientId.  Obtain this by creating a free application at [https://app.quantimo.do/api/v2/apps](https://app.quantimo.do/api/v2/apps).

parameters.name: response_type
parameters.description: If the value is code, launches a Basic flow, requiring a POST to the token endpoint to obtain the tokens. If the value is token id_token or id_token token, launches an Implicit flow, requiring the use of Javascript at the redirect URI to retrieve tokens from the URI #fragment.

parameters.name: scope
parameters.description: Scopes include basic, readmeasurements, and writemeasurements. The "basic" scope allows you to read user info (displayname, email, etc). The "readmeasurements" scope allows one to read a user's data. The "writemeasurements" scope allows you to write user data. Separate multiple scopes by a space.

parameters.name: redirect_uri
parameters.description: The redirect URI is the URL within your client application that will receive the OAuth2 credentials.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: An opaque string that is round-tripped in the protocol; that is to say, it is returned as a URI parameter in the Basic flow, and in the URI

get.description: Client provides authorization token obtained from /api/v3/oauth2/authorize to this endpoint and receives an access token. Access token can then be used to query different API endpoints of QuantiModo. ### Request Access Token After user approves your access to the given scope form the https:/app.quantimo.do/v2/oauth2/authorize endpoint, you'll receive an authorization code to request an access token. This time make a `POST` request to `/api/v2/oauth/access_token` with parameters including: * `grant_type` Can be `authorization_code` or `refresh_token` since we are getting the `access_token` for the first time we don't have a `refresh_token` so this must be `authorization_code`. * `code` Authorization code you received with the previous request. * `redirect_uri` Your application's redirect url. ### Refreshing Access Token Access tokens expire at some point, to continue using our api you need to refresh them with `refresh_token` you received along with the `access_token`. To do this make a `POST` request to `/api/v2/oauth/access_token` with correct parameters, which are: * `grant_type` This time grant type must be `refresh_token` since we have it. * `clientId` Your application's client id. * `client_secret` Your application's client secret. * `refresh_token` The refresh token you received with the `access_token`. Every request you make to this endpoint will give you a new refresh token and make the old one expired. So you can keep getting new access tokens with new refresh tokens. ### Using Access Token Currently we support 2 ways for this, you can't use both at the same time. * Adding access token to the request header as `Authorization: Bearer {access_token}` * Adding to the url as a query parameter `?access_token={access_token}` You can read more about OAuth2 from [here](http://oauth.net/2/)

parameters.name: clientId
parameters.description: This is the unique ID that QuantiModo uses to identify your application. Obtain a client id by emailing info@quantimo.do.

parameters.name: client_secret
parameters.description: This is the secret for your obtained clientId. QuantiModo uses this to validate that only your application uses the clientId.

parameters.name: grant_type
parameters.description: Grant Type can be 'authorization_code' or 'refresh_token'

parameters.name: code
parameters.description: Authorization code you received with the previous request.

parameters.name: response_type
parameters.description: If the value is code, launches a Basic flow, requiring a POST to the token endpoint to obtain the tokens. If the value is token id_token or id_token token, launches an Implicit flow, requiring the use of Javascript at the redirect URI to retrieve tokens from the URI #fragment.

parameters.name: scope
parameters.description: Scopes include basic, readmeasurements, and writemeasurements. The "basic" scope allows you to read user info (displayname, email, etc). The "readmeasurements" scope allows one to read a user's data. The "writemeasurements" scope allows you to write user data. Separate multiple scopes by a space.

parameters.name: redirect_uri
parameters.description: The redirect URI is the URL within your client application that will receive the OAuth2 credentials.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: An opaque string that is round-tripped in the protocol; that is to say, it is returned as a URI parameter in the Basic flow, and in the URI

get.summary: First Setp in Social Authentication flow with JWT Token
get.description:
Here is the flow for how social authentication works with a JWT Token
1.**Client:** The client needs to open popup with social auth url (`https://app/quantimo.do/api/v2/auth/social/login?provider={provider}&redirectUrl={url}`) of server with `provider` and `redirectUrl`. (Url should be registered with our social apps. Facebook and Twitter are fine with any redirect url with the same domain base url but Google needs exact redirect url.) 2.**Server:** The QM server will redirect user to that provider to get access. 3.**Client:** After successful or failed authentication, it will be redirected to given `redirectUrl` with code or error. 4.**Client:** The client needs to get that code and needs to send an Ajax request to server at `https://app.quantimo.do/api/v2/auth/social/authorizeCode?provider={provider}&code={authorizationCode}` 5.**Server:** The QM server will authorize that code from the social connection and will authenticate user and will retrieve user info. 6.**Server:** The QM server will try to find existing user by unique identity. If the user already exists then it will login. Otherwise, it will create new user and will then login. 7.**Server:** Once user is found/created, it will return a JWT token for that user in the response.

parameters.name: redirectUrl
parameters.description: The redirect URI is the URL within your client application that will receive the OAuth2 credentials. Url should be registered with our social apps. Facebook and Twitter are fine with any redirect url with the same domain base url but Google needs exact redirect url.

parameters.name: provider
parameters.description: The current options are `google` and `facebook`.

get.summary: Second Step in Social Authentication flow with JWT Token
get.description:
Here is the flow for how social authentication works with a JWT Token
1.**Client:** The client needs to open popup with social auth url (`https://app/quantimo.do/api/v2/auth/social/login?provider={provider}&redirectUrl={url}`) of server with `provider` and `redirectUrl`. (Url should be registered with our social apps. Facebook is fine with any redirect url with the same domain base url but Google needs exact redirect url.) 2.**Server:** The QM server will redirect user to that provider to get access. 3.**Client:** After successful or failed authentication, it will be redirected to given `redirectUrl` with code or error. 4.**Client:** The client needs to get that code and needs to send an Ajax request to server at `https://app.quantimo.do/api/v2/auth/social/authorizeCode?provider={provider}&code={authorizationCode}` 5.**Server:** The QM server will authorize that code from the social connection and will authenticate user and will retrieve user info. 6.**Server:** The QM server will try to find existing user by unique identity. If the user already exists then it will login. Otherwise, it will create new user and will then login. 7.**Server:** Once user is found/created, it will return a JWT token for that user in the response.

parameters.name: code
parameters.description: Authorization code obtained from the provider.

parameters.name: provider
parameters.description: The current options are `google` and `facebook`.

get.description: If you are using native authentication via Facebook or Google SDKs then you should use the following flow. 1.**Client:** Using native authentication via your native mobile app, get an access token using the instructions provided by the Facebook SDK (https://developers.facebook.com/docs/facebook-login) or Google (https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/OAuth2) 2.**Client:** Send an Ajax request with provider name and access token on `https://app.quantimo.do/api/v2/auth/social/authorizeToken?provider={provider}&accessToken={accessToken}&refreshToken={refreshToken}` (`refreshToken` is optional) 3.**Server:** Server will try to get user info and will find existing user by unique identity. If user exist then it will do a login for that or it will create new user and will do login 4.**Server:** Once user is found/created, it will return a JWT token for that user in response 5.**Client:** After getting the JWT token to get a QM access token follow these steps and include your JWT token in them as a header (Authorization: Bearer **{yourJWThere}**) or as a url parameter (https://app.quantimo.do/api/v2/oauth/authorize?token={yourJWThere}).

parameters.name: refreshToken
parameters.description: Optional refresh token obtained from Google or FB native SDK

parameters.name: accessToken
parameters.description: User's OAuth2 access token obtained from Google or FB native SDK

parameters.name: provider
parameters.description: The current options are `google` and `facebook`.

get.description: Get a list of the available measurement units
Get a list of the categories of measurement units such as 'Distance', 'Duration', 'Energy', 'Frequency', 'Miscellany', 'Pressure', 'Proportion', 'Rating', 'Temperature', 'Volume', and 'Weight'.
Returns user info.  If no userId is specified, returns info for currently authenticated user

post.summary: Post or update user tags or ingredients
post.description: This endpoint allows users to tag foods with their ingredients.  This information will then be used to infer the user intake of the different ingredients by just entering the foods. The inferred intake levels will then be used to determine the effects of different nutrients on the user during analysis.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: Contains the new user tag data

delete.description: Delete previously created user tags or ingredients.

parameters.name: taggedVariableId
parameters.description: This is the id of the variable being tagged with an ingredient or something.

parameters.name: tagVariableId
parameters.description: This is the id of the ingredient variable whose value is determined based on the value of the tagged variable.

post.summary: Update User Settings for a Variable
post.description: Users can change the parameters used in analysis of that variable such as the expected duration of action for a variable to have an effect, the estimated delay before the onset of action. In order to filter out erroneous data, they are able to set the maximum and minimum reasonable daily values for a variable.

parameters.name: userVariables
parameters.description: Variable user settings data

400.description: The received JSON was invalid or malformed

get.description: Get variables for which the user has measurements. If the user has specified variable settings, these are provided instead of the common variable defaults.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Common variable id

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Original name of the variable (supports exact name match only)

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The name of the data source that created the variable (supports exact name match only). So if you have a client application and you only want variables that were last updated by your app, you can include the name of your app here

parameters.name: numberOfRawMeasurements
parameters.description: Filter variables by the total number of measurements that they have. This could be used of you want to filter or sort by popularity.

parameters.name: lastSource
parameters.description: Limit variables to those which measurements were last submitted by a specific source. So if you have a client application and you only want variables that were last updated by your app, you can include the name of your app here. (supports exact name match only)

get.description: This endpoint retrieves an array of all public variables. Public variables are things like foods, medications, symptoms, conditions, and anything not unique to a particular user. For instance, a telephone number or name would not be a public variable.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Original name of the variable (supports exact name match only)

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The name of the data source that created the variable (supports exact name match only). So if you have a client application and you only want variables that were last updated by your app, you can include the name of your app here

parameters.name: numberOfRawMeasurements
parameters.description: Filter variables by the total number of measurements that they have. This could be used of you want to filter or sort by popularity.

parameters.name: lastSource
parameters.description: Limit variables to those which measurements were last submitted by a specific source. So if you have a client application and you only want variables that were last updated by your app, you can include the name of your app here. (supports exact name match only)

delete.description: Users can delete all of their measurements for a variable

parameters.description: Id of the variable whose measurements should be deleted

get.description: The variable categories include Activity, Causes of Illness, Cognitive Performance, Conditions, Environment, Foods, Location, Miscellaneous, Mood, Nutrition, Physical Activity, Physique, Sleep, Social Interactions, Symptoms, Treatments, Vital Signs, and Work.

post.description: This is to enable users to indicate their opinion on the plausibility of a causal relationship between a treatment and outcome. QuantiModo incorporates crowd-sourced plausibility estimations into their algorithm. This is done allowing user to indicate their view of the plausibility of each relationship with thumbs up/down buttons placed next to each prediction.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: Contains the cause variable, effect variable, and vote value.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The cause and effect variable names for the predictor vote to be deleted.
parameters array

image.description: URL to the image of the connector logo

getItUrl.description: URL to a site where one can get this device or application

connected.description: True if the authenticated user has this connector enabled

connectInstructions.description: URL and parameters used when connecting to a service

totalMeasurementsInLastUpdate.description: Number of measurements obtained during latest update

value.description: This specifies the order of conversion steps starting with 0

cause.description: Variable name of the cause variable for which the user desires correlations.

causeVariableCategoryName.description: Variable category of the cause variable.

causeChanges.description: Number of changes in the predictor variable (a.k.a the number of experiments)

causeVariableCombinationOperation.description: The way cause measurements are aggregated

causeVariableDefaultUnitId.description: Unit Id of the predictor variable

causeVariableName.description: Variable name of the cause variable for which the user desires correlations.

correlationCoefficient.description: Pearson correlation coefficient between cause and effect measurements

createdAt.description: When the record was first created. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

durationOfAction.description: The amount of time over which a predictor/stimulus event can exert an observable influence on an outcome variable’s value. For instance, aspirin (stimulus/predictor) typically decreases headache severity for approximately four hours (duration of action) following the onset delay.

effect.description: Variable name of the effect variable for which the user desires correlations.

effectVariableCategoryName.description: Variable category of the effect variable.

effectSize.description: Magnitude of the effects of a cause indicating whether it's practically meaningful.

effectVariableId.description: Magnitude of the effects of a cause indicating whether it's practically meaningful.

effectVariableName.description: Variable name of the effect variable for which the user desires correlations.

gaugeImage.description: Illustrates the strength of the relationship

numberOfPairs.description: Number of points that went into the correlation calculation

onsetDelay.description: The amount of time in seconds that elapses after the predictor/stimulus event before the outcome as perceived by a self-tracker is known as the “onset delay”. For example, the “onset delay” between the time a person takes an aspirin (predictor/stimulus event) and the time a person perceives a change in their headache severity (outcome) is approximately 30 minutes.

predictorExplanation.description: HIGHER Remeron predicts HIGHER Overall Mood

qmScore.description: Value representing the significance of the relationship as a function of crowdsourced insights, predictive strength, data quantity, and data quality

reverseCorrelation.description: Correlation when cause and effect are reversed. For any causal relationship, the forward correlation should exceed the reverse correlation.

significanceExplanation.description: Using a two-tailed t-test with alpha = 0.05, it was determined that the change...

statisticalSignificance.description: A function of the effect size and sample size

studyAbstract.description: These data suggest with a high degree of confidence...

studyBackground.description: In order to reduce suffering through the advancement of human knowledge...

studyDesign.description: This study is based on data donated by one QuantiModo user...

studyLimitations.description: As with any human experiment, it was impossible to control for all potentially confounding variables...

studyLinkDynamic.description: Url for the interactive study within the web app

studyLinkFacebook.description: Url for sharing the study on Facebook

studyLinkGoogle.description: Url for sharing the study on Google+

studyLinkTwitter.description: Url for sharing the study on Twitter

studyLinkStatic.description: Url for sharing the statically rendered study on social media

studyObjective.description: The objective of this study is to determine...

studyTitle.description: N1 Study HIGHER Remeron predicts HIGHER Overall Mood

timestamp.description: Time at which correlation was calculated

updatedAt.description: When the record in the database was last updated. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local.

valuePredictingHighOutcome.description: cause value that predicts an above average effect value (in default unit for cause variable)

valuePredictingHighOutcomeExplanation.description: Overall Mood, on average, 34% HIGHER after around 3.98mg Remeron

valuePredictingLowOutcome.description: cause value that predicts a below average effect value (in default unit for cause variable)

valuePredictingLowOutcomeExplanation.description: Overall Mood, on average, 4% LOWER after around 0mg Remeron

measurementItems.description: Array of timestamps, values, and optional notes

variableName.description: ORIGINAL name of the variable for which we are creating the measurement records

sourceName.description: Name of the application or device used to record the measurement values

combinationOperation.description: Way to aggregate measurements over time. Options are "MEAN" or "SUM". SUM should be used for things like minutes of exercise.  If you use MEAN for exercise, then a person might exercise more minutes in one day but add separate measurements that were smaller.  So when we are doing correlational analysis, we would think that the person exercised less that day even though they exercised more.  Conversely, we must use MEAN for things such as ratings which cannot be SUMMED.

variableName.description: Name of the variable for which we are creating the measurement records

sourceName.description: Application or device used to record the measurement values

startTimeString.description: Start Time for the measurement event in UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"

startTimeEpoch.description: Seconds between the start of the event measured and 1970 (Unix timestamp)

value.description: Converted measurement value in requested unit

originalunitAbbreviatedName.description: Original Unit of measurement as originally submitted

unitAbbreviatedName.description: Abbreviated name for the unit of measurement

variableId.description: Variable id of the measurement to be deleted

startTime.description: Start time of the measurement to be deleted

id.description: Variable id of the measurement to be updated

startTime.description: The new timestamp for the the event in epoch seconds (optional)

value.description: The new value of for the measurement (optional)

note.description: The new note for the measurement (optional)

variableId.description: Id of the variable whose measurements should be deleted

id.description: Id of the TrackingReminder to be deleted

modifiedValue.description: Optional value to be recorded instead of the tracking reminder default value

action.description: track records a measurement for the notification.  snooze changes the notification to 1 hour from now. skip deletes the notification.

variableId.description: Id for the variable to be tracked

defaultValue.description: Default value to use for the measurement when tracking

reminderStartTime.description: Earliest time of day at which reminders should appear in UTC HH:MM:SS format

reminderEndTime.description: Latest time of day at which reminders should appear in UTC HH:MM:SS format

reminderSound.description: String identifier for the sound to accompany the reminder

reminderFrequency.description: Number of seconds between one reminder and the next

popUp.description: True if the reminders should appear as a popup notification

sms.description: True if the reminders should be delivered via SMS

email.description: True if the reminders should be delivered via email

notificationBar.description: True if the reminders should appear in the notification bar

latestTrackingReminderNotificationRemind.description: UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  timestamp for the reminder time of the latest tracking reminder notification that has been pre-emptively generated in the database

lastTracked.description: UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  timestamp for the last time a measurement was received for this user and variable

startTrackingDate.description: Earliest date on which the user should be reminded to track in YYYY-MM-DD format

stopTrackingDate.description: Latest date on which the user should be reminded to track in YYYY-MM-DD format

updatedAt.description: When the record in the database was last updated. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local.

variableName.description: Name of the variable to be used when sending measurements

variableCategoryName.description: Name of the variable category to be used when sending measurements

unitAbbreviatedName.description: Abbreviated name of the unit to be used when sending measurements

combinationOperation.description: The way multiple measurements are aggregated over time

id.description: id for the specific PENDING tracking remidner

trackingReminderId.description: id for the repeating tracking remidner

variableId.description: Id for the variable to be tracked

pendingReminderTime.description: UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  timestamp for the specific time the variable should be tracked in UTC.  This will be used for the measurement startTime if the track endpoint is used.

defaultValue.description: Default value to use for the measurement when tracking

reminderSound.description: String identifier for the sound to accompany the reminder

popUp.description: True if the reminders should appear as a popup notification

sms.description: True if the reminders should be delivered via SMS

email.description: True if the reminders should be delivered via email

notificationBar.description: True if the reminders should appear in the notification bar

updatedAt.description: When the record in the database was last updated. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format. Time zone should be UTC and not local.

variableName.description: Name of the variable to be used when sending measurements

variableCategoryName.description: Name of the variable category to be used when sending measurements

unitAbbreviatedName.description: Abbreviated name of the unit to be used when sending measurements

combinationOperation.description: The way multiple measurements are aggregated over time

minimumAllowedValue.description: The minimum allowed value for measurements. While you can record a value below this minimum, it will be excluded from the correlation analysis.

maximumAllowedValue.description: The maximum allowed value for measurements. While you can record a value above this maximum, it will be excluded from the correlation analysis.

taggedVariableId.description: This is the id of the variable being tagged with an ingredient or something.

tagVariableId.description: This is the id of the ingredient variable whose value is determined based on the value of the tagged variable.

conversionFactor.description: Number by which we multiply the tagged variable value to obtain the tag variable (ingredient) value

createdAt.description: When the record was first created. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

updatedAt.description: When the record in the database was last updated. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

parentId.description: ID of the parent variable if this variable has any parent

defaultUnitId.description: ID of unit to use for this variable

minimumAllowedValue.description: The minimum allowed value for measurements. While you can record a value below this minimum, it will be excluded from the correlation analysis.

maximumAllowedValue.description: The maximum allowed value for measurements. While you can record a value above this maximum, it will be excluded from the correlation analysis.

fillingValue.description: When it comes to analysis to determine the effects of this variable, knowing when it did not occur is as important as knowing when it did occur. For example, if you are tracking a medication, it is important to know when you did not take it, but you do not have to log zero values for all the days when you haven't taken it. Hence, you can specify a filling value (typically 0) to insert whenever data is missing.

joinWith.description: The Variable this Variable should be joined with. If the variable is joined with some other variable then it is not shown to user in the list of variables

onsetDelay.description: The amount of time in seconds that elapses after the predictor/stimulus event before the outcome as perceived by a self-tracker is known as the “onset delay”. For example, the “onset delay” between the time a person takes an aspirin (predictor/stimulus event) and the time a person perceives a change in their headache severity (outcome) is approximately 30 minutes.

durationOfAction.description: The amount of time over which a predictor/stimulus event can exert an observable influence on an outcome variable’s value. For instance, aspirin (stimulus/predictor) typically decreases headache severity for approximately four hours (duration of action) following the onset delay.

causeOnly.description: A value of 1 indicates that this variable is generally a cause in a causal relationship.  An example of a causeOnly variable would be a variable such as Cloud Cover which would generally not be influenced by the behaviour of the user

measurementsAtLastAnalysis.description: Number of measurements at last analysis

lastOriginalValue.description: Last original value which is stored

numberOfCorrelations.description: Number of correlations for this variable

lastSuccessfulUpdateTime.description: When this variable or its settings were last updated

minimumRecordedValue.description: Minimum recorded value of this variable

maximumRecordedDailyValue.description: Maximum recorded daily value of this variable

experimentStartTime.description: Earliest measurement start_time to be used in analysis. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

experimentEndTime.description: Latest measurement start_time to be used in analysis. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

createdAt.description: When the record was first created. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

updatedAt.description: When the record in the database was last updated. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

outcome.description: Outcome variables (those with `outcome` == 1) are variables for which a human would generally want to identify the influencing factors. These include symptoms of illness, physique, mood, cognitive performance, etc.  Generally correlation calculations are only performed on outcome variables

sources.description: Comma-separated list of source names to limit variables to those sources

timestamp.description: Timestamp for the measurement event in epoch time (unixtime)

note.description: Optional note to include with the measurement

variableCategoryName.description: Variable category like Mood, Sleep, Physical Activity, Treatment, Symptom, etc.

unitAbbreviatedName.description: Abbreviated name of the default unit for the variable

abbreviatedUnitId.description: Id of the default unit for the variable

sources.description: Comma-separated list of source names to limit variables to those sources

minimumAllowedValue.description: The minimum allowed value for measurements. While you can record a value below this minimum, it will be excluded from the correlation analysis.

maximumAllowedValue.description: The maximum allowed value for measurements. While you can record a value above this maximum, it will be excluded from the correlation analysis.

combinationOperation.description: Way to aggregate measurements over time. Options are "MEAN" or "SUM". SUM should be used for things like minutes of exercise.  If you use MEAN for exercise, then a person might exercise more minutes in one day but add separate measurements that were smaller.  So when we are doing correlational analysis, we would think that the person exercised less that day even though they exercised more.  Conversely, we must use MEAN for things such as ratings which cannot be SUMMED.

fillingValue.description: When it comes to analysis to determine the effects of this variable, knowing when it did not occur is as important as knowing when it did occur. For example, if you are tracking a medication, it is important to know when you did not take it, but you do not have to log zero values for all the days when you haven't taken it. Hence, you can specify a filling value (typically 0) to insert whenever data is missing.

joinWith.description: The Variable this Variable should be joined with. If the variable is joined with some other variable then it is not shown to user in the list of variables.

joinedVariables.description: Array of Variables that are joined with this Variable

parent.description: Id of the parent variable if this variable has any parent

subVariables.description: Array of Variables that are sub variables to this Variable

onsetDelay.description: The amount of time in seconds that elapses after the predictor/stimulus event before the outcome as perceived by a self-tracker is known as the “onset delay”. For example, the “onset delay” between the time a person takes an aspirin (predictor/stimulus event) and the time a person perceives a change in their headache severity (outcome) is approximately 30 minutes.

durationOfAction.description: The amount of time over which a predictor/stimulus event can exert an observable influence on an outcome variable’s value. For instance, aspirin (stimulus/predictor) typically decreases headache severity for approximately four hours (duration of action) following the onset delay.

updated.description: When this variable or its settings were last updated

causeOnly.description: A value of 1 indicates that this variable is generally a cause in a causal relationship.  An example of a causeOnly variable would be a variable such as Cloud Cover which would generally not be influenced by the behaviour of the user.

outcome.description: Outcome variables (those with `outcome` == 1) are variables for which a human would generally want to identify the influencing factors. These include symptoms of illness, physique, mood, cognitive performance, etc.  Generally correlation calculations are only performed on outcome variables.

rawMeasurementsAtLastAnalysis.description: The number of measurements that a given user had for this variable the last time a correlation calculation was performed. Generally correlation values are only updated once the current number of measurements for a variable is more than 10% greater than the rawMeasurementsAtLastAnalysis.  This avoids a computationally-demanding recalculation when there's not enough new data to make a significant difference in the correlation.

cause.description: Cause variable name for the correlation to which the vote pertains

effect.description: Effect variable name for the correlation to which the vote pertains

createdAt.description: When the record was first created. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

updatedAt.description: When the record in the database was last updated. Use UTC ISO 8601 "YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss"  datetime format

scopes.basic: Allows you to read user info (displayname, email, etc).
scopes.readmeasurements: Allows one to read a user's data
scopes.writemeasurements: Allows you to write user data
